title: 110_s3391
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Police Administrative Technical Corrections Act of 2008". It pertains to the administrative authorities of the Chief of the Capitol Police. The United States Capitol Police Administrative Technical Corrections Act of 2008 clarifies certain hiring authorities related to the Chief Administrative Officer within the Capitol Police, including their appointment process and compensation. The United States Capitol Police Administrative Technical Corrections Act of 2008 makes amendments to the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 2001 regarding the Chief of the Capitol Police's rate of pay, administrative provisions, certifying officers, and personnel actions. The Chief of the Capitol Police is authorized to appoint, hire, discipline, and set employment terms for Capitol Police employees. Section 1823 of the Revised Statutes of the United States is repealed. The Act of Mar. 3, 1875 proviso is also affected. The Act of Mar. 3, 1875 proviso is repealed, and the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 is amended regarding the Capitol Police Board. No impact on current proceedings or personnel. The amendments in the subsection do not affect current Capitol Police officers or employees. Section 2802 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2001 is amended to deposit reimbursements for law enforcement assistance to the United States Capitol Police. The effective date of these changes is retroactive to the enactment of the Act in 2001. The Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 2005 is amended to require prior notification to specific committees before deployment outside jurisdiction. SEC. 3. GENERAL COUNSEL TO THE CHIEF OF POLICE AND THE UNITED STATES CAPITOL POLICE. The text amends the Legal Representation Authority regarding the General Counsel to the Chief of Police and the United States Capitol Police. It also includes a technical and conforming amendment related to House Resolution 661 from the Ninety-fifth Congress. The Ninety-fifth Congress repealed a law enacted in 1977 regarding the General Counsel to the Chief of Police and the United States Capitol Police. This repeal does not affect the current General Counsel's status. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF AUTHORITIES REGARDING CERTAIN PERSONNEL BENEFITS. No lump sum payment allowed for unused compensatory time for terminated officers or employees of the United States Capitol Police, except as permitted under specific legislation. Repeal of outdated provisions related to compensatory time for Capitol Police. The repeal of outdated provisions related to compensatory time for Capitol Police officers and employees, including the removal of section 1924 of title 2, United States Code and the last paragraph under the heading "Administrative Provisions" in the Senate's appropriation act. The Chief of the Capitol Police may now provide compensation for overtime work of exempt individuals under specific criteria. The Chief of the Capitol Police can compensate exempt individuals for overtime work under specific criteria, with a monetary value set for the overtime work. The total compensation for overtime work and regular compensation paid to the individual in a pay period cannot exceed the annual compensation cap allocated per pay period. Exempt individuals of the Capitol Police are defined as officers or employees who are either classified as exempt from certain labor regulations or whose pay rate is not specified by law. The Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 2003 is amended to repeal Section 1009. The repeal does not apply to overtime work performed before the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. OTHER MISCELLANEOUS TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. Repeal of obsolete procedures for initial appointment of Chief Administrative Officer, repeal of requirement for officers to purchase own uniforms, and repeal of references to officers and privates in authorities relating to House and Senate office buildings. The Legislative Branch Appropriation Act of 1907 and 1943 are amended to replace references to officers and privates of the Capitol Police with the United States Capitol Police. Additionally, the U.S. Capitol Police and Library of Congress Police Merger Implementation Act of 2007 is clarified by repealing duplicate provisions. In the Appropriations Act, 2008, section 1004 is repealed, restoring any previously amended or repealed laws. This does not affect the U.S. Capitol Police and Library of Congress Police Merger Implementation Act of 2007. The Chief of Police's authority is addressed by repealing certain provisions in the United States Code. The provisions related to the selection process of Capitol Police officers are repealed, as stated in 2 U.S.C. 1901. This repeal is in accordance with the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act of 2003. The selection process for Capitol Police officers, as outlined in the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act of 2003, is being amended. The Chief of the Capitol Police will now be appointed by the Capitol Police Board and serve at their pleasure. The previous sentence regarding the appointment process is being restored to the Revised Statutes of the United States. The amendment to the selection process for Capitol Police officers will be retroactively applied to the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act of 2003.
